headline: Time to Redo the Math on Tax Reform Prospects
summary: Any investors who think the failure of health-care reform was somehow a positive because it cleared the way for tax reform may be about to be rapidly disabused of that notion.

headline: Sanctuary City Mayors Vow to Protect Immigrants
summary: Leaders of sanctuary cities reaffirmed their commitment to shield immigrants after the Trump administration said it will cut Justice Department funds to cities that don’t fully cooperate with federal immigration authorities.

headline: No Evidence Linking London Attacker to Islamic State or al Qaeda, Police Say
summary: Police said there was no evidence to suggest the attacker who killed four in London last week had links to Islamic State or al Qaeda, but said he had a clear interest in Islamist extremism.

headline: New York State Lawmakers Divided on Justice Reform for Minors
summary: With less than a week before the New York state budget is due, lawmakers remain divided on a number of polarizing policy issues, and concerned about how future federal legislation may upend the state’s finances.

headline: Brazil’s Vale Names Fabio Schvartsman as CEO
summary: Brazilian mining giant Vale SA said its board approved the selection of Fabio Schvartsman to replace outgoing Chief Executive Murilo Ferreira.

headline: Hartford, ICE in Dispute Over Agents Posing as Local Police
summary: The mayor of Hartford, Conn. is embroiled in a dispute with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement after city officials said federal agents wore outfits which made them seem to be local police officers.

headline: Rate Increases Should Be Done Gradually, Fed’s Kaplan Says
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan said he will likely support more interest rate increases as long as the economy continues to see job market gains and a continued move back toward a 2% inflation rise.

headline: Olive Garden Owner Pays $780M for Cheddar’s Chain
summary: Casual-restaurant chain Cheddar’s Scratch Kitchen will soon share ownership with the likes of Olive Garden, LongHorn Steakhouse and the Capital Grille.

headline: Michigan to Pay Flint $87 Million to Replace Lead-Tainted Water Lines
summary: Michigan agreed to pay $87 million so Flint can replace up to 18,000 lead service lines to help it recover from a tainted-water crisis under a proposed agreement to resolve a lawsuit brought by a group of citizens and an environmental group last year.

headline: The Man Putin Hates Most
summary: Alexei Navalny gets another jail term amid opposition protests.

headline: Letter to Beijing
summary: Eleven countries, but not the U.S., slam China’s legal crackdown.

headline: Broadway Musical Offers Free MetroCards to Boost Ticket Sales
summary: To increase its box-office, the Broadway musical ‘In Transit’ is offering patrons a free seven-day unlimited MetroCard worth $32 when they buy a full-priced seat for a limited time.

headline: Prosecutors Recommend 3 Years in Prison for ‘Bridgegate’ Principals
summary: Federal prosecutors are seeking about three years in prison for two former allies of New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie who were convicted of illegally closing lanes at the George Washington Bridge in 2013.

headline: The G-Man Takes On Donald Trump
summary: FBI Director James Comey isn’t supposed to be America’s political referee.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Brief Career as an Ad Man
summary: His visits to our agency were a master class in investing.

headline: America Is Ill-Prepared to Counter Russia’s Information Warfare

headline: Saudi Arabia Puts U.S. Energy Producers to a Test—and They Ace It
summary: It’s entirely feasible for America to become a far bigger oil exporter, even one of the biggest.

headline: Notable & Quotable: No News Is Good News?
summary: ‘The press has gotten away from its traditional job of just telling readers what the news is.’

headline: Pimco Settles Contract Suit With Bill Gross for $81 Million
summary: Pacific Investment Management settled the breach-of-contract suit filed by its co-founder and former star bond manager, Bill Gross, for $81 million.

headline: The GOP Entitlement Caucus
summary: The Freedom Caucus wastes the best shot at fiscal restraint in years.

headline: Bustle Turns Political in Latest $12 Million Funding Round
summary: When Bleacher Reporter co-founder Bryan Goldberg launched a site for millennial women, he received plenty of criticism. Now, Bustle is valued at almost $200 million and pushing into political reporting and more video.

summary: U.S. aid becomes a transfer payment for terrorists.

headline: So Much for Donald Mussolini
summary: Remember when Trump was going to roll over U.S. checks and balances?

headline: U.S. Supreme Court Won’t Review Visa, Mastercard Fees Case
summary: The Supreme Court declined an invitation to rescue a $7.25 billion antitrust settlement between Visa Inc. and MasterCard Inc. and retailers that argued the card companies’ rules led to artificially inflated fees.

headline: Coding Schools Build Tuition-Back Guarantees Into Business Model
summary: Guarantees may be a scary prospect for four-year colleges, but they are built into the business model of for-profit coding boot camps, which depends on students seeing a solid return on their investment.

headline: Fed’s Evans: Three 2017 Rate Rises Plausible, Four Possible if Inflation Picks Up
summary: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said the U.S. central bank could raise short-term interest rates four times this year if inflation picks up, but suggested lifting rates three times remains more plausible.

headline: Parents’ Spring Dilemma: To Test or Not To Test
summary: Parents are grappling again with questions about whether to have their children participate in state tests starting this week in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Arguments on Appeals Process for Corporate Insider Disputes
summary: The country’s top court agreed to hear arguments on how deeply appellate-level judges should investigate disputes that arise in corporate bankruptcy cases over potentially conflicted executives and other insiders.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of March 28, 2017

headline: Valeant Former CEO Sues Company Over Unmade Payments
summary: Michael Pearson, ex-CEO of Valeant Pharmaceuticals, is suing the embattled drugmaker for refusing to pay him more than 3 million company shares that he said he is owed.

headline: Photos of the Day: March 27
summary: In photos selected Monday by Wall Street Journal editors, a girl visits the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, the Chinese premier receives a traditional Maori greeting, a Syrian man looks at an unexploded missile, and more.

headline: Mother of Bronx Teen Fatally Shot by Officer Criticizes City
summary: When a New York Police Department officer who fatally shot an unarmed Bronx teenager was found guilty in an internal disciplinary trial, Mayor Bill de Blasio said he hoped the process brought the family of the 18-year-old, Ramarley Graham, “a measure of justice.”

headline: Jim Gianopulos Named Head of Paramount Pictures
summary: Jim Gianopulos, the longtime head of Twentieth Century Fox, has been tapped to turn around Viacom Inc.’s troubled movie studio.

headline: Alexion Names New CEO Following Internal Sales-Practice Probe
summary: Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc. named new a chief executive Monday, months after the company’s top leadership abruptly stepped down amid an internal investigation into sales practices.

headline: Dollar Falls to Lowest Level Since November
summary: The dollar fell amid rising doubts that the White House will be able to push through promised tax cuts and infrastructure spending.

headline: Port Authority Bathroom Arrests Spur Lawsuit
summary: A federal lawsuit alleges Port Authority of New York & New Jersey police of wrongly arresting men on charges of public lewdness after they used the bathroom in its Manhattan bus terminal.

headline: Theresa May Urges Brexit-Weary Scotland to Remain in U.K.
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May tried to rally support for maintaining Scotland’s place in the U.K. on Monday, seeking to hold her country together as she prepares to break away from the European Union.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case that Could Limit Lawsuits Against Companies for Disclosure Failures
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court agreed to consider whether publicly traded companies can be sued for securities fraud by third parties for omitting “known trends or uncertainties” in filings to shareholders.

headline: Elevate Credit Makes New IPO Push
summary: Online lender Elevate Credit revived plans for an initial public offering on Monday, becoming the latest firm to try to ride the wave of investor demand for new issues.

headline: Adient Looks to Expand Into Aviation Market with Boeing
summary: Automotive seating supplier Adient is considering entering the aerospace business, announcing plans Monday to work with Boeing to explore development of seating for aircraft.

headline: Kushner to Oversee Office of American Innovation at White House
summary: President Donald Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner, will oversee the new Office of American Innovation at the White House tasked with replicating private-sector efficiency inside the federal government.

headline: Yield on 10-Year Treasury Note Falls to One-Month Low
summary: The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell to a one-month low Monday as investors lost appetite for riskier markets after House Republicans pulled their health-care bill before a vote in Congress last week.

headline: Can Tech Speed Up Emergency Room Care?
summary: A New York hospital system tests a new way to use telemedicine, where E.R. doctors examine patients without being in the same room.

headline: Uber Resumes Self-Driving-Vehicle Program After Arizona Accident
summary: Uber Technologies is putting its autonomous vehicles back on city streets after an accident involving one of them in Tempe, Ariz., caused the company to halt its test program.

headline: Babies, Demographics and Economic Growth
summary: Bret Stephens’s main contention in “‘Other People’s Babies’” (Global View, March 21) is that America needs immigration because of demographic decline, and it wouldn’t hurt our culture. Many of the immigrants here and abroad don’t appear to want to assimilate.

headline: Russian Activist Alexei Navalny Emerges as a Chief Opponent to Putin
summary: Lawyer and anti-corruption activist Alexei Navalny has leveraged the tools of social media and online video to present one of the most serious domestic political challenges to Russian President Vladimir Putin in recent years.

headline: Democrats Are Right to Criticize Netanyahu
summary: Andrew Stein and Doug Schoen should be careful when throwing around the “anti-Israel” label against Democrats. President Obama’s relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu surely was strained, but not because of anything President Obama did (“Democrats Turn Against Israel,” op-ed, March 20).

headline: This Is a Great Racket if You Are a Union Beneficiary
summary: The tipping point has been reached when entrenched, unionized, public employees can use their political clout to extract special privileges not available to the taxpayers who pay their salaries.

headline: Natural Gas Declines, Reversing Early Gains
summary: Natural-gas prices settled lower Monday, reversing early gains as fears of oversupply keep a rally in check.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Robo Adviser to Cost More Than Rivals’ Options
summary: Wells Fargo, which will begin testing its robo-advisory service in coming months, plans to charge more and require a higher minimum balance than some competitors.

headline: The North Korea Sanctions Myth

headline: Taiwan’s Answer to Chinese Economic Coercion
summary: The U.S. can help reduce Taipei’s dangerous dependence on Beijing.

headline: Brexit Fuels 18% Decline in U.K. Office Building Prices
summary: U.K. offices were sold at an 18% discount last year, a sign that the economic uncertainty surrounding plans to exit the European Union, as well as the real estate cycle maturing, took a toll on the market.

summary: U.S. hospital stocks rose Monday amid a broader market downturn as investors welcomed the stalling of White House efforts to overturn the Affordable Care Act.

summary: Crude prices inched lower Monday, weighed down by investor skepticism that major oil producers will extend a deal to curtail global supply beyond June.

headline: Carnival Shareholders Are Having Fun Now, Too
summary: Carnival shares are at records, having fully recovered from last year’s Zika-related concerns, and appear to have more upside if bookings hold up and international growth remains strong.

summary: Charles Murray speaks at a university—and no one gets hurt.

headline: Metals: Gold Hits One-Month High
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-month high on Monday, as a weaker dollar and doubts about the Trump agenda pushed up the precious metal.

headline: Tronc’s Shareholder Raises Corporate Governance Questions
summary: Tronc’s second-largest shareholder has sent a letter to the board raising questions about corporate governance and demanding they raise a limit on his ownership stake amid an increasingly hostile fight with the company’s biggest investor.

headline: Voices: Steps 401(k) Advisers Can Take to Avoid Legal Claims
summary: Adviser Voices: Conor Weir, managing director at Retirement Benefits Group in Long Beach, Calif., says advisers who help manage 401(k) plans should fully disclose fees and offer client services that show value for the fees charged.

headline: U.S. Soccer Takes Its Reclamation Project on the Road
summary: Bruce Arena got off to a strong start in his return as U.S men’s national team coach, but needs to continue the momentum against Panama on Tuesday night

headline: Facebook Wants to Help You Be a Better Citizen
summary: Facebook is getting more serious about the role it plays in your political life. The social network rolled out a civic outreach tool in the U.S. that identifies your elected officials, sends reminders to vote and goads you to pick up the phone.

headline: Mexican Auto Output Soars as Trump Administration Settles In
summary: The prospect of lowering the U.S. auto industry’s reliance on “Made in Mexico” became thornier during the Trump administration’s early days, as the number of popular pickups and SUVs flooding in from south of the border rose sharply in January and February.

headline: For Trump, ‘Extreme Vetting’ Has Wide Scope

headline: Lawyer Invokes Immunity for FBI, Prosecutors in Hedge-Fund Probe

headline: Olympic Athletes Have Nothing on China’s Lunch-Delivery Guys
summary: Competing services, staffed mostly by young men on electric scooters, tear through Chinese streets at breakneck speeds and sprint up skyscraper stairs, making up to 10 deliveries per hour.

headline: China Tanked Oil Once, It Can Do It Again

headline: Bill Nye’s Favorite Things

summary: Uber Technologies suspended testing of its autonomous vehicles after one of them was involved in an accident in Tempe, Ariz., a dramatic halt to one of the most high-profile self-driving programs.

summary: After cutting more than $40 billion of costs since the financial crisis, big banks are considering ways to slash still more from their back-office budgets. One effort aims to create a joint venture that allows banks to share trade processes and technology.

summary: Amazon is facing a setback in its efforts to modernize brick-and-mortar retail as technical glitches delay the opening of its first cashierless convenience store.

summary: A recent study found that students who took a basic financial-education course exhibited lower levels of impulsive behavior.

summary: The former investment strategist to George Soros is putting his palatial Sabine Farm in Greenwich, Conn., on the market.

summary: The perk allow collectors to quickly tap equity in valuable artwork and other collectibles they consign for sale.

summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

summary: Bank owned by big insurer Ping An is exposed to the plunge in China Huishan Dairy’s shares.

summary: NATO is preparing to expand its satellite-communications capability with contracts worth about $1.85 billion later this year as it prepares to field a new fleet of drones.

headline: Metal Prices Hammered by China Curbs, Trump Uncertainty
summary: Steel and iron-ore futures fell sharply in Asia, following fresh curbs on financing in China’s housing sector and pessimism over the speed of Donald Trump’s infrastructure initiatives.

summary: Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel of Germany won the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne as the season opened.

headline: Foreign Investors Flock to Iran as U.S. Firms Stay on Sidelines
summary: Many foreign investors are rushing into Iran’s promising market after its nuclear accord, setting off skirmishes among European and Asian companies eager to gain a step on more cautious American rivals.

headline: Congress Gears Up for Fight Over Spending
summary: President Donald Trump and GOP leaders enter their next big battle facing stubborn opposition in both parties that increases Republicans’ worries that they will need more Democratic support than previously expected to avert a government shutdown.

headline: After GOP Bill’s Failure, Health-Law Lawsuit Takes Center Stage
summary: President Donald Trump and GOP lawmakers, seeking to regroup following the collapse of the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act, have an option for gutting the health law relatively quickly: They could halt billions in payments insurers get under the law.

headline: Sanctuary Cities to Be Barred From Justice Department Funds, Sessions Says
summary: The Trump administration said it would withhold federal criminal-justice grants from cities, counties and states that don’t fully cooperate with federal immigration authorities, a first strike in the new administration’s battle against so-called sanctuary cities.

headline: U.S. Boosts Military Backing for Saudi-Led Coalition in Yemen
summary: The Trump administration has significantly increased military support for Sunni Arab states fighting al Qaeda and Iranian-backed militias in Yemen, said U.S. and Arab officials, drawing the U.S. deeper into the two-year civil war there.

headline: This Can Pass the House
summary: How the GOP can get beyond its Friday failure.

headline: Dow Suffers Longest Losing Streak Since 2011
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average notched its longest losing streak in nearly six years, reflecting investors’ doubts about the Trump administration’s ability to enact its agenda.

headline: NFL Backs Oakland Raiders’ Plan to Move to Las Vegas
summary: In a startling move for a league long opposed to gambling, the National Football League’s owners voted Monday to allow the Oakland Raiders to relocate to Las Vegas, a city that just a few years ago was considered off limits.

headline: Saudi Arabia Drops Tax Rates for Oil Firms Ahead of Aramco IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia dropped the tax rate on its oil industry, laying the groundwork for a highly anticipated initial public offering of its state-owned energy company, Saudi Aramco, and a broader overhaul of its oil-focused economy.

headline: Tabitha Soren on the Other Meaning of the ‘Moneyball’ A’s

summary: Far-right French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen sought advice from a clandestine group of bankers, executives and government officials called “Les Horaces” that is part of the same establishment she has railed against.

headline: In Populists vs. Establishment, the Establishment Strikes Back
summary: Is the populist tide cresting? It’s too early to draw definitive conclusions, but the forces of nationalism and populism suffered setbacks in elections in the Netherlands, Australia and Germany in recent days, Gerald F. Seib writes.

headline: South African Treasury Chief’s Recall Rattles Rand, Stocks, Bonds

headline: There Is Coconut Everywhere

headline: Master Photographer Irving Penn’s Retrospective Opens This Month, Including Unseen Paintings
summary: Irving Penn was far more comfortable behind the camera than in front of it. A new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reveals his personal passions.

summary: Here's your morning roundup of the biggest marketing, advertising and media industry news and happenings.

headline: More Chinese Consumers Say No to Fake Goods
summary: In China, counterfeit merchandise hasn’t gone away by any means. But a growing number of Chinese consumers are now willing to pay more for authentic goods such as Mickey Mouse sweatshirts and Bart Simpson baseball caps.

summary: Delivering up-to-the minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

headline: A Correction Now Might Not Be So Bad, Some Investors Say
summary: Many investors and analysts worry the postelection rally has outpaced the fundamentals, such as corporate earnings, that drive stock gains over time; some say a 10% pullback from the March 1 high could be healthy by deflating pockets of froth and providing buying opportunities.
